newsitem.title: INDIA: India rupee ends up, tests 35.75 per dlr, RBI buys.
newsitem.headline: India rupee ends up, tests 35.75 per dlr, RBI buys.

text.p: The Indian rupee ended Friday sharply up against the US currency at 35.750/755 per dollar against its previous close of 35.35.790/795, dealers said.
They said the rupee touched 35.75 in trade just before close, its highest point since 35.7475 on May 5.
Dealers said the rupee traded at a high of 35.75 and a low of 35.775 on Friday with most of the day's business done around 35.77 per dollar.
"The rupee tested the 35.75 barrier in late trade but ran into Reserve Bank of India (RBI) intervention at that level," said a dealer at a private bank.
"RBI bought dollars at around 35.755 but the buying was in very small amounts...$25 million at the most," he said.
Dealers said they expected a more serious test of the 35.75 barrier on Monday.

"I think the (35.75) mark will be tested in earnest on Monday," said another dealer. "There was some pretty good dollar selling today and given the supply, we can expect some upward pressure on the rupee on Monday."
The RBI was however expected to buy dollars more aggressively in case 35.75 looked like breaking, he said.
"I think today's action (by RBI) was more by way of a signal," the dealer said. "The market does not really expect 35.75 to be broken, given RBI's actions in the past."

"The last time this mark looked like being broken, the RBI hit the market in a big way," he added. "Given that some liquidity is going out of the system through Wednesday's auction, there is sufficient leeway for the RBI to buy dollars aggressively."
The RBI auctions 30 billion rupees of government bonds on May 28.
"Earlier, the RBI was worried about the effects of its dollar purchases on domestic monetary expansion," the dealer said. "But with the bond outflows coming up, they have some leeway."
Dealers said forward premiums ended marginally up in range-bond trade.
November-delivery dollars ended at a premium of 88/90 paise against the previous close of 86/89, they said.
"Premiums opened up on fears of tightening liquidity due to the bond issue," said a dealer. "But the movement was not much as demand and supply are well-matched at the moment."
